44OUDHpGdn7fjO1MfyKPU2.name: Tương Ưng Sakka
44OUDHpGdn7fjO1MfyKPU2.introduction: The “Linked Discourses with Sakka” contains 25 discourses with verses telling stories involving Sakka, the Lord of the Thirty-Three gods. Many of these discourses are relatively lengthy, featuring substantive prose and extended dialogues in verse. Sakka is shown devoted to the Buddha, defending Buddhist virtues of kindness and forgiveness, even in the waging of war with the demons.

73k6jSlsG5ZNKuJAVXOm4Q.name: Tương Ưng Dạ Xoa
73k6jSlsG5ZNKuJAVXOm4Q.introduction: The “Linked Discourses with Spirits” contains 12 discourses with verses telling the encounters between the Buddha—or in one case the monk Anuruddha—and various spirits (yahhka). The spirits were local deities worshiped in ancient India, of a lower order than the gods and Brahmās. While in later forms of Buddhism, such spirits were typically depicted as malevolent or dangerous, in the early texts they are more ambivalent, and many of them are friendly, merely asking Dhamma questions, or extolling Dhamma virtues like mindfulness. That’s not to say they couldn’t be scary, and several discourses reveal a more ferocious aspect. Particularly interesting is the emphasis on the love that the female spirits feel for their children.

2Mu7xdRDPoDwG9cZpA4kTo.name: Tương Ưng Rừng
2Mu7xdRDPoDwG9cZpA4kTo.introduction: The “Linked Discourses in the Woods” contains 14 discourses with verses telling the experiences of certain monks living the woods. Typically the monk is slack or negligent in some way, and a deity appears to call them out and encourage them to greater diligence.

5wsB0337PkXLVLRGUdUCfa.name: Tương Ưng Trưởng Lão Vangìsa
5wsB0337PkXLVLRGUdUCfa.introduction: The “Linked Discourses with Vaṅgīsa” contains 12 discourses with verses spoken by Vaṅgīsa, the most renowned poet of early Buddhism. His verses have a sophistication and personal vulnerability that stamp them as perhaps the most distinctive literary voice of the early texts. Several of these discourses speak of his insecurities and struggles, and how he was helped to overcome them. Others speak from his joyous devotion to the Buddha and the Saṅgha, and of his final triumph.

1Ix1Uwz2ZIwPtgeYVEFEtn.name: Tương Ưng Bà-La-Môn
1Ix1Uwz2ZIwPtgeYVEFEtn.introduction: The “Linked Discourses with Brahmins” contains 22 discourses featuring the Buddha interacting with various members of the brahmanical caste. The brahmins were the custodians of the brahmanical scriptures and traditions, and saw themselves as the spiritual elite of society. A central platform of the Buddha’s ethical teaching was that one’s worth is determined by one’s deeds, not by caste. This was a direct challenge to brahmanical authority, and a number of discourses have an understandably combative air to them. But the brahmins were a diverse community, and it’s just as common to find them relating to the Buddha with respect and gratitude.

3ueHL3d2eZvqk6A56aXJwK.name: Tương Ưng Phạm Thiên
3ueHL3d2eZvqk6A56aXJwK.introduction: The “Linked Discourses with Brahmās” contains 15 discourses featuring high brahmanical deities. Most commonly we meet the “Great Brahmā”, regarded as the creator God, but he is merely one of a class of deities, and here we meet several others. Brahmā is depicted here and elsewhere in early Buddhist texts in a respectful way, regarded as a glorious deity reborn in his realm due to powerful good kamma. As here, he frequently acts as a champion for the Buddhist cause. However, like all the gods, he is still under the influence of delusion and has nor escaped rebirth.

PM5T87ogpaJxHGcf4Ujn8.name: Tương Ưng Tỷ Kheo Ni
PM5T87ogpaJxHGcf4Ujn8.introduction: The “Linked Discourses with Nuns” contains 10 discourses describing occasions when various nuns retreat to a forest for meditation, only to be challenged by Māra. The verses here partly overlap with the Therīgāthā, though there are some that are unique to this context, and we also have a prose narrative to flesh out the context. Māra’s challenges are various; sometimes he is sexist, alleging that women are weak in wisdom (SN 5.2). Several of these short texts are among the most frequently quoted of all the suttas.

7wS5ouJDqW7pu73CYpPcFW.name: Tương Ưng Ác Ma
7wS5ouJDqW7pu73CYpPcFW.introduction: The “Linked Discourses with Māra” contains 25 discourses featuring Māra, the god of temptation, deceit, and death. In these discourses, Māra typically appears in some terrifying or beguiling form, hoping to disturb the Buddha, or else he challenges the Buddha with a critical verse. Like the previous section, the narrative prose here is substantive. The Buddha recognizes him at once and exposes his deceit in a verse. Māra also appears throughout the next collection, where the nuns take him on.

2sFiAkQql2k59xsap2b8xv.name: Tương Ưng Kosala
2sFiAkQql2k59xsap2b8xv.introduction: The “Linked Discourses with the Kosalan” contains 25 discourses featuring King Pasenadi of Kosala. Pasenadi shines through in the early texts as a complex human figure, one with foibles and foolishness, but with a great devotion and capacity to grow. He appears frequently elsewhere in the suttas; MN 87 tells the story of how Queen Mallikā led him to the Dhamma. Here Mallikā appears again, and in SN 3.8 she shows how she is not afraid to challenge her king. The suttas in this collection typically set the verses in substantive prose narratives, illustrating the struggles and problems that beset a king intent on Dhamma who must nonetheless rule in a world with spies, sacrifices, punishments, wars, and the many temptations of royal life.

2RNpaAxcmqVZxvHcYANHPe.name: Tương Ưng Thiên Tử
2RNpaAxcmqVZxvHcYANHPe.introduction: The “Linked Discourses on Gods” contains 30 discourses, each one of which depicts the Buddha in conversation with a god. Here the term devaputta is used, rather than devatā in the previous saṁyutta. The difference is purely nominal and there is no difference in the meaning. The style of discourses is similar to the “Linked Discourses on Deities”, although here there is a greater emphasis on the theme of renunciation. A number of these discourses are regularly recited in modern Theravāda; the Tāyana verses on diligent striving at SN 2.8 are often recited by monastics, while the discourses on the sun and the moon (SN 2.9 and SN 2.10) are popular protection chants, which are also found in Tibetan.

3YVWLkOTOS1YCVmORZZMcS.name: Tương Ưng Chư Thiên
3YVWLkOTOS1YCVmORZZMcS.introduction: The “Linked Discourses on Gods” contains 30 discourses, each one of which depicts the Buddha in conversation with a god. Here the term devaputta is used, rather than devatā in the previous saṁyutta. The difference is purely nominal and there is no difference in the meaning. The style of discourses is similar to the “Linked Discourses on Deities”, although here there is a greater emphasis on the theme of renunciation. A number of these discourses are regularly recited in modern Theravāda; the Tāyana verses on diligent striving at SN 2.8 are often recited by monastics, while the discourses on the sun and the moon (SN 2.9 and SN 2.10) are popular protection chants, which are also found in Tibetan.

1735dD7CG3PBg6uzW4aNCp.name: Kinh Gò Mối
1735dD7CG3PBg6uzW4aNCp.introduction: In a curious discourse laden with evocative imagery, a deity presents a riddle to a mendicant, who seeks an answer from the Buddha.

36tfU6J3pVE5bzRLvBiLAs.name: Tiểu Kinh Sư Tử Hống
36tfU6J3pVE5bzRLvBiLAs.introduction: The Buddha declares that only those following his path can genuinely experience the four stages of awakening. This is because, while much is shared with other systems, none of them go so far as to fully reject all attachment to the idea of a self.

5WTjbgFQrmLqQepFoinCOU.name: Kinh Tất Cả Các Lậu Hoặc
5WTjbgFQrmLqQepFoinCOU.introduction: The diverse problems of the spiritual journey demand a diverse range of responses. Rather than applying the same solution to every problem, the Buddha outlines seven methods of dealing with defilements, each of which works in certain cases.

4sN0l45p1zgXvAEFucXhzz.name: Kinh Subha
4sN0l45p1zgXvAEFucXhzz.introduction: Working hard is not valuable in and of itself; what matters is the outcome. And just as in lay life, spiritual practice may or may not lead to fruitful results.

6BUXe6HzrkxN2mwYq8ZuaT.name: Kinh Vàsettha
6BUXe6HzrkxN2mwYq8ZuaT.introduction: Two brahmin students ask the Buddha about what makes a brahmin: birth or deeds? the Buddha points out that, while the species of animals are determined by birth, for humans what matters is how you chose to live. This discourse anticipates the modern view that there are no such things as clearly defined racial differences among humans.

N6F2M8CeKn0TBgVp6E8QT.name: Kinh Dhànanjàni
N6F2M8CeKn0TBgVp6E8QT.introduction: A corrupt tax-collector is redeemed by his encounter with Venerable Sāriputta.

431S8a9QatOQO0lgQOE7WT.name: Kinh Esukàrì
431S8a9QatOQO0lgQOE7WT.introduction: A brahmin claims that one deserves service and privilege depending on caste, but the Buddha counters that it is conduct, not caste, that show a person’s worth.

57AVAR2ynF5lt41qhtMwac.name: Kinh Cankì
57AVAR2ynF5lt41qhtMwac.introduction: The reputed brahmin Caṅkī goes with a large group to visit the Buddha, despite the reservations of other brahmins. A precocious student challenges the Buddha, affirming the validity of the Vedic scriptures. The Buddha gives a detailed explanation of how true understanding gradually emerges through spiritual education.

3gk8pcyipyytTNE0g2K1gm.name: Kinh Ghotamukha
3gk8pcyipyytTNE0g2K1gm.introduction: A brahmin denies that there is such a thing as a principled renunciate life, but Venerable Udena persuades him otherwise.

2ot5a6Cs6yCkOvyfcFAit5.name: Kinh Assalàyana
2ot5a6Cs6yCkOvyfcFAit5.introduction: A precocious brahmin student is encouraged against his wishes to challenge the Buddha on the question of caste. His reluctance turns out to be justified.

5kNYN9xIPEkuRpchs9jrSj.name: Kinh Sela
5kNYN9xIPEkuRpchs9jrSj.introduction: A brahmanical ascetic named Keṇiya invites the entire Saṅgha for a meal. When the brahmin Sela sees what is happening, he visits the Buddha and expresses his delight in a moving series of devotional verses.

l5TIXwQ1IfDSsqyQ9ITpg.name: Kinh Brahmàyu
l5TIXwQ1IfDSsqyQ9ITpg.introduction: The oldest and most respected brahmin of the age sends a student to examine the Buddha, and he spends several months following his every move before reporting back. Convinced that the Buddha fulfills an ancient prophecy of the Great Man, the brahmin becomes his disciple.

1UZAnuiAynWjL4U7iGwvFQ.name: Kinh Kannakatthala
1UZAnuiAynWjL4U7iGwvFQ.introduction: King Pasenadi questions the Buddha on miscellaneous matters: caste, omniscience, and the gods among them.

bHLHU878ToDorDdoOFKKr.name: Kinh Bàhitika
bHLHU878ToDorDdoOFKKr.introduction: King Pasenadi takes a chance to visit Venerable Ānanda, where he asks about skillful and unskillful behavior, and what is praised by the Buddha. He offers Ānanda a valuable cloth in gratitude.

7KauGvSvGVtmdAGK0xdJwv.name: Kinh Ái Sanh
7KauGvSvGVtmdAGK0xdJwv.introduction: A rare glimpse into the marital life of King Pasenadi, and how he is led to the Dhamma by his Queen, the incomparable Mallikā. She confirms the Buddha’s teaching that our loved ones bring us sorrow; but that’s not something a husband, father, and king wants to hear.

4mqaJ65fVkaeIPUFdfzpnM.name: Kinh Angulimàla
4mqaJ65fVkaeIPUFdfzpnM.introduction: Ignoring warnings, the Buddha ventures into the domain of the notorious killer Aṅgulimāla and succeeds in converting him to the path of non-violence. After becoming a monk Aṅgulimāla still suffered for his past deeds, but only to a small extent. He uses his new commitment to non-violence to help a woman in labor.

5qTWGRHT6ZJ05jVvk2P0zz.name: Kinh Vương Tử Bồ Đề
5qTWGRHT6ZJ05jVvk2P0zz.introduction: Admitting that he used to believe that pleasure was to be gained through pain, the Buddha explains how his practice showed him the fallacy of that idea.

mzYMYUNBAom2v1yoxGPCe.name: Kinh Madhurà
mzYMYUNBAom2v1yoxGPCe.introduction: In Madhurā, towards the north-eastern limit of the Buddha’s reach during his life, King Avantiputta asks Venerable Mahākaccāna regarding the brahmanical claim to be the highest caste.

7NImrhznT2JEWLDKv38QB.name: Kinh Makhàdeva
7NImrhznT2JEWLDKv38QB.introduction: A rare extended mythic narrative, telling of an ancient kingly lineage and their eventual downfall.

6EpgAMp0vT1kZ7wx721ry3.name: Kinh Ratthapàla
6EpgAMp0vT1kZ7wx721ry3.introduction: A wealthy young man, Raṭṭhapāla, has a strong aspiration to go forth, but has to prevail against the reluctance of his parents. Even after he became a monk, his parents tried to persuade him to disrobe. The discourse ends with a moving series of teachings on the fragility of the world.

3NaoIIAZm7KQuxUXabBrMD.name: Kinh Ghatìkàra
3NaoIIAZm7KQuxUXabBrMD.introduction: The Buddha relates an unusual account of a past life in the time of the previous Buddha, Kassapa. At that time he was not interested in Dhamma, and had to be forced to go see the Buddha. This discourse is important in understanding the development of the Bodhisattva doctrine.

zBKiY3JGMXGVooXgS4pFF.name: Kinh Vekhanassa
zBKiY3JGMXGVooXgS4pFF.introduction: Starting off similar to the previous, the Buddha goes on to explain that one is not converted to his teaching just because of clever arguments, but because you see in yourself the results of the practice.

5mdoShR1B08tVNvx6TXtuL.name: Tiểu Kinh Sakuludàyi (Thiện Sanh Ưu Đà Di)
5mdoShR1B08tVNvx6TXtuL.introduction: A wanderer teaches his doctrine of the “highest splendor” but is unable to give a satisfactory account of what that means. The Buddha memorably compares him to someone who is in love with an idealized women who he has never met.

hFN3YZ0PHyCaWMThlpxZD.name: Kinh Samanamandikà
hFN3YZ0PHyCaWMThlpxZD.introduction: A wanderer teaches that a person has reached the highest attainment when they keep four basic ethical precepts. The Buddha’s standards are considerably higher.

3AhmpPKli0LpS151kCzvsd.name: Đại Kinh Sakuludàyin
3AhmpPKli0LpS151kCzvsd.introduction: Unlike many teachers, the Buddha’s followers treat him with genuine love and respect, since they see the sincerity of his teaching and practice.

3YKW1TWSaSH6UleSH2nOhF.name: Kinh Sandaka
3YKW1TWSaSH6UleSH2nOhF.introduction: Venerable Ānanda teaches a group of wanderers how there are many different approaches to the spiritual life, many of which lead nowhere.

6Oz9lII0sEFQCKin2Qjdjk.name: Kinh Màgandiya
6Oz9lII0sEFQCKin2Qjdjk.introduction: Accused by a hedonist of being too negative, the Buddha recounts the luxury of his upbringing, and his realization of how little value there was in such things. Through renunciation he found a far greater pleasure.

2XMVQT6lxogXNuTlqjz46r.name: Kinh Trường Trảo
2XMVQT6lxogXNuTlqjz46r.introduction: Deftly outmaneuvering an extreme skeptic, the Buddha discusses the outcomes of belief and disbelief. Rather than getting stuck in abstractions, he encourages staying close to the feelings one experiences.

1r8HMcfDUHfWWMUlTBCOmV.name: Đại Kinh Vacchagotta
1r8HMcfDUHfWWMUlTBCOmV.introduction: In the final installment of the “Vacchagotta trilogy”, Vacchagotta lets go his obsession with meaningless speculation, and asks about practice.

5CloWOhSY8jo7f7ssbuSqU.name: Kinh Dạy Vacchagotta Về Lửa
5CloWOhSY8jo7f7ssbuSqU.introduction: Refusing to take a stance regarding useless metaphysical speculations, the Buddha illustrates the spiritual goal with the simile of a flame going out.

5AkmM0aaqoUFVcPZs7XwNW.name: Kinh Dạy Vacchagotta Về Tam Minh
5AkmM0aaqoUFVcPZs7XwNW.introduction: The Buddha denies being omniscient, and sets forth the three higher knowledges that form the core of his awakened insight.

5YHu8mpOFy9F6FZ3ID2yLS.name: Kinh Kìtàgiri
5YHu8mpOFy9F6FZ3ID2yLS.introduction: A third discourse that presents the health benefits of eating in one part of the day, and the reluctance of some mendicants to follow this.

5uyRcW6h6IZTHr9vgeyyjr.name: Kinh Gulisàni
5uyRcW6h6IZTHr9vgeyyjr.introduction: A monk comes down to the community from the wilderness, but doesn’t behave properly. Venerable Sāriputta explains how a mendicant should behave, whether in forest or town.

7brAkPql1sFILR3jOXWeVM.name: Kinh Nalakapàna
7brAkPql1sFILR3jOXWeVM.introduction: Those who practice do so not because they are failures, but because they aspire to higher freedom. When he speaks of the attainments of disciples, the Buddha does so in order to inspire.

3YzjZiVkdFjkN0vGKFW5Vl.name: Kinh Càtumà
3YzjZiVkdFjkN0vGKFW5Vl.introduction: After dismissing some unruly monks, the Buddha is persuaded to relent, and teaches them four dangers for those gone forth.

7Lm3wgEk3w85AzF30JVDv0.name: Kinh Ví Dụ Con Chim Cáy
7Lm3wgEk3w85AzF30JVDv0.introduction: Again raising the rule regarding eating, but this time as a reflection of gratitude for the Buddha in eliminating things that cause complexity and stress. The Buddha emphasizes how attachment even to little things can be dangerous.

72ByCUsUKcJ4vgtTV0f1Tv.name: Kinh Bhaddàli
72ByCUsUKcJ4vgtTV0f1Tv.introduction: A monk refuses to follow the rule forbidding eating after noon, but is filled with remorse and forgiven.

1t6xTDGCrwTgvzcYyq1Epm.name: Đại Kinh Màlunkyà
1t6xTDGCrwTgvzcYyq1Epm.introduction: A little baby has no wrong views or intentions, but the underlying tendency for these things is still there. Without practicing, they will inevitably recur.

3S9cAyuYEn5nOk2naqqT5x.name: Tiểu Kinh Màlunkyà
3S9cAyuYEn5nOk2naqqT5x.introduction: A monk demands that the Buddha answer his metaphysical questions, or else he will disrobe. The Buddha compares him to a man struck by an arrow, who refuses treatment until he can have all his questions about the arrow and the archer answered.

7rsYuQ7whY1dcT3eMGMzpw.name: Đại Kinh Giáo Giới La-Hầu-La
7rsYuQ7whY1dcT3eMGMzpw.introduction: The Buddha tells Rāhula to meditate on not-self, which he immediately puts into practice. Seeing him, Venerable Sāriputta advises him to develop breath meditation, but the Buddha suggests a wide range of different practices first.

6CAX2DVlnIrXxnxY1ye6RP.name: Kinh Giáo Giới La-Hầu-La Ở Rừng Ambala
6CAX2DVlnIrXxnxY1ye6RP.introduction: Using the “object lesson” of a cup of water, the Buddha explains to his son, Rāhula, the importance of telling the truth and reflecting on one’s motives.

5XiYycGiKtPVZkkUvhCpF1.name: Kinh Không Gì Chuyển Hướng
5XiYycGiKtPVZkkUvhCpF1.introduction: The Buddha teaches a group of uncommitted householders how to use a rational reflection to arrive at practices and principles that are guaranteed to have a good outcome, even if we don’t know all the variables.

2zt7TrOdqd2Q2Ibij0TG6h.name: Kinh Nhiều Cảm Thọ
2zt7TrOdqd2Q2Ibij0TG6h.introduction: The Buddha resolves a disagreement on the number of kinds of feelings that he taught, pointing out that different ways of teaching are appropriate in different contexts, and should not be a cause of disputes. He goes on to show the importance of pleasure in developing higher meditation.

CbvKmFRi413Qqv1Lny4gy.name: Kinh Vương Tử Vô Úy
CbvKmFRi413Qqv1Lny4gy.introduction: The leader of the Jains, Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, gives his disciple Prince Abhaya a dilemma to pose to the Buddha, supposing that this will show his weakness. Things don’t go quite as planned.

2P8YOnrOdGebqyAJbfxYrA.name: Kinh Hạnh Con Chó
2P8YOnrOdGebqyAJbfxYrA.introduction: Some ascetics in ancient India undertook extreme practices, such as a vow to behave like an ox or a dog. The Buddha meets two such individuals, and is reluctantly pressed to reveal the kammic outcomes of such practice.

ZIp7COMbNgp3F8zQs8hMe.name: Kinh Ưu-Ba-Ly
ZIp7COMbNgp3F8zQs8hMe.introduction: The Buddha disagrees with a Jain ascetic on the question of whether physical or mental deeds are more important. When he hears of this, the Jain disciple Upāli decides to visit the Buddha and refute him, and proceeds despite all warnings.

2jkHiTutXX6lklWHZ85hTX.name: Kinh Jìvaka
2jkHiTutXX6lklWHZ85hTX.introduction: The Buddha’s personal doctor, Jīvaka, hears criticisms of the Buddha’s policy regarding eating meat, and asks him about it.

4EIBUXayn9NcooC5cukUjQ.name: Kinh Potaliya
4EIBUXayn9NcooC5cukUjQ.introduction: When Potaliya got upset at being referred to as “householder”, the Buddha quizzed him as to the true nature of attachment and renunciation.

2pkmnRN5F7YEuhy8u5mLFR.name: Kinh Hữu Học
2pkmnRN5F7YEuhy8u5mLFR.introduction: The Buddha is invited by his family, the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu, to inaugurate a new community hall. He invites Venerable Ānanda to explain in detail the stages of spiritual practice for a lay trainee.

7ph98cKnrfz2oQN581tvVX.name: Kinh Bát Thành
7ph98cKnrfz2oQN581tvVX.introduction: Asked by a householder to teach a path to freedom, Venerable Ānanda explains no less than eleven meditative states that may serve as doors to the deathless.

7i9gwrDCbVU5GUvpU09iT.name: Kinh Kandaraka
7i9gwrDCbVU5GUvpU09iT.introduction: The Buddha discusses mindfulness meditation with lay practitioners. Contrasting the openness of animals with the duplicity of humans, he explains how to practice in a way that causes no harm to oneself or others.

6d6gfx53VQaBN2GXXatRJD.name: Kinh Hàng Ma
6d6gfx53VQaBN2GXXatRJD.introduction: Māra, the trickster and god of death, tried to annoy Moggallāna. He not only failed but was subject to a stern sermon warning of the dangers of attacking the Buddha’s disciples.

3pXATdWruhYEHRWHy12AzK.name: Kinh Phạm Thiên Cầu Thỉnh
3pXATdWruhYEHRWHy12AzK.introduction: The Buddha ascends to a high heavenly realm where he engages in a cosmic contest with a powerful divinity, who had fallen into the delusion that he was eternal and all-powerful.

2GilOicUetl157pqaycAlI.name: Kinh Kosambiya
2GilOicUetl157pqaycAlI.introduction: Despite the Buddha’s presence, the monks of Kosambi fell into a deep and bitter dispute. The Buddha taught the reluctant monks to develop love and harmony, reminding them of the state of peace that they sought.

6oNoGkLE9Q36sgrI9mUHLs.name: Kinh Tư Sát
6oNoGkLE9Q36sgrI9mUHLs.introduction: While some spiritual teachers prefer to remain in obscurity, the Buddha not only encouraged his followers to closely investigate him, but gave them a detailed and demanding method to do so.

4p75pjfRy1J5tcBQWxjTIF.name: Đại Kinh Pháp Hành
4p75pjfRy1J5tcBQWxjTIF.introduction: While we all want to be happy, we often find the opposite happens. The Buddha explains why.

6bDfPwdoyFXZPMggJSkKbo.name: Tiểu Kinh Phương Quảng
6bDfPwdoyFXZPMggJSkKbo.introduction: The layman Visākha asks the nun Dhammadinnā about various difficult matters, including some of the highest meditation attainments. The Buddha fully endorses her answers.

2zeQu6EP7WSLSJkdBP64ni.name: Kinh Veranjaka
2zeQu6EP7WSLSJkdBP64ni.introduction: Similar to the previous. The Buddha explains the conduct leading to rebirth in higher or lower states, including detailed explanations of the ten core practices.

23JbaEMJTrafSNfiHIRg3n.name: Đại Kinh Phương Quảng
23JbaEMJTrafSNfiHIRg3n.introduction: A series of questions and answers between Sāriputta and Mahākoṭṭhita, examining various subtle and abstruse aspects of the teachings.

67UFiqZvyBBtS2uFbgKBxT.name: Kinh Sàleyyaka
67UFiqZvyBBtS2uFbgKBxT.introduction: The Buddha explains to a group of brahmins the conduct leading to rebirth in higher or lower states, including detailed explanations of the ten core practices which lay people should undertake, and which also form the basis for liberation.

13VOKahbK37twksM78B3sD.name: Tiểu Kinh Xóm Ngựa
13VOKahbK37twksM78B3sD.introduction: The labels of being a spiritual practitioner don’t just come from external trappings, but from sincere inner change.

1YWy5Yryzo3dmcXCwE5ym3.name: Tiểu Kinh Đoạn Tận Ái
1YWy5Yryzo3dmcXCwE5ym3.introduction: Moggallāna visits the heaven of Sakka, the lord of gods, to see whether he really understands what the Buddha is teaching.

xtzWnhyqRy5Ohb0gI2r6l.name: Đại Kinh Saccaka
xtzWnhyqRy5Ohb0gI2r6l.introduction: In a less confrontational meeting, the Buddha and Saccaka discuss the difference between physical and mental development. The Buddha gives a long account of the various practices he did before awakening, detailing the astonishing lengths he took to mortify the body.

2uE7OIWcpBNm0X8pykNK0q.name: Đại Kinh Người Chăn Bò
2uE7OIWcpBNm0X8pykNK0q.introduction: For eleven reasons a cowherd is not able to properly look after a herd. The Buddha compares this to the spiritual growth of a mendicant.

67St7Rw0YtvwW6MQZYYc5S.name: Tiểu Kinh Saccaka
67St7Rw0YtvwW6MQZYYc5S.introduction: Saccaka was a debater, who challenged the Buddha to a contest. Despite his bragging, the Buddha is not at all perturbed at his attacks.

3vZuB6Zjy0xswcKhlN9sYx.name: Tiểu Kinh Người Chăn Bò
3vZuB6Zjy0xswcKhlN9sYx.introduction: Drawing parallels with a cowherd guiding his herd across a dangerous river, the Buddha presents the various kinds of enlightened disciples who cross the stream of transmigration.

46uAolbvvPqJpK6BbUIRmP.name: Đại Kinh Rừng Sừng Bò
46uAolbvvPqJpK6BbUIRmP.introduction: Several senior mendicants, reveling in the beauty of the night, discuss what kind of practitioner would adorn the park. They take their answers to the Buddha, who praises their answers, but gives his own twist.

1qI89nXRINUmHbjbCvdK4k.name: Tiểu Kinh Pháp Hành
1qI89nXRINUmHbjbCvdK4k.introduction: The Buddha explains how taking up different practices may have harmful or beneficial results. The memorable simile of the creeper shows how insidious temptations can be.

48pavgazsN5rGmTEOG2fqT.name: Đại Kinh Đoạn Tận Ái
48pavgazsN5rGmTEOG2fqT.introduction: To counter the wrong view that a self-identical consciousness transmigrates from one life to the next, the Buddha teaches dependent origination, showing that consciousness invariably arises dependent on conditions.

4G6CU37UlDa4JnhktjrgXo.name: Đại Kinh Xóm Ngựa
4G6CU37UlDa4JnhktjrgXo.introduction: The Buddha encourages the mendicants to live up to their name, by actually practicing in a way that meets or exceeds the expectations people have for renunciants.

6iiFihFUDR4ixCfDkJz0kU.name: Kinh Pháp Trang Nghiêm
6iiFihFUDR4ixCfDkJz0kU.introduction: King Pasenadi, near the end of his life, visits the Buddha, and shows moving devotion and love for his teacher.

2LMiFqFtKPWIKPd0wRa5Bo.name: Tiểu Kinh Rừng Sừng Bò
2LMiFqFtKPWIKPd0wRa5Bo.introduction: The Buddha comes across three mendicants practicing diligently and harmoniously, and asks them how they do it. Reluctant to disclose their higher attainments, they explain how they deal with the practical affairs of living together. But when pressed by the Buddha, they reveal their meditation attainments.

19pULvsQuIxUMCmWLOaTY0.name: Tiểu Kinh Dụ Lõi Cây
19pULvsQuIxUMCmWLOaTY0.introduction: Similar to the previous. After the incident with Devadatta, the Buddha cautions the mendicants against becoming complacent and points to liberation as the true heart of the teaching.

2NIDb8oRZ7vDx4YQXS6Mgz.name: Kinh Căn Tu Tập
2NIDb8oRZ7vDx4YQXS6Mgz.introduction: A brahmin teacher advocates that purification of the senses consists in simply avoiding seeing and hearing things. The Buddha explains that it is not about avoiding sense experience, but understanding it and learning to not be affected by sense experience.

10oSNhL2EfgPqb5RXkmVZC.name: Kinh Khất Thực Thanh Tịnh
10oSNhL2EfgPqb5RXkmVZC.introduction: The Buddha notices Venerable Sāriputta’s glowing complexion, which is the result of his deep meditation. He then presents a series of reflections by which a mendicant can be sure that they are worthy of their alms-food.

62ISYii9KwdiThPENdgyHu.name: Kinh Nói Cho Dân Nagaravinda
62ISYii9KwdiThPENdgyHu.introduction: In discussion with a group of householders, the Buddha helps them to distinguish those spiritual practitioners who are truly worthy of respect.

4ThLD7jiC60TLYRDACSfox.name: Đại Kinh Sáu Xứ
4ThLD7jiC60TLYRDACSfox.introduction: Explains how insight into the six senses is integrated with the eightfold path and leads to liberation.

5Cgu3yeP3vMuDNdl35Jzvh.name: Kinh Sáu Sáu
5Cgu3yeP3vMuDNdl35Jzvh.introduction: The Buddha analyzes the six senses from six perspectives, and demonstrates the emptiness of all of them.

1BTuv4GHRMGLzwW6l0BLEF.name: Tiểu Kinh Giáo Giới La-Hầu-La
1BTuv4GHRMGLzwW6l0BLEF.introduction: The Buddha takes Rāhula with him to a secluded spot in order to lead him on to liberation.

2rRabK9J1Y074vxISwdUI3.name: Kinh Giáo Giới Nandaka
2rRabK9J1Y074vxISwdUI3.introduction: When asked to teach the nuns, Venerable Nandaka proceeds by inviting them to engage with his discourse and ask if there is anything that needs further explanation.

75PN3a4IsTBNgpgGqKt8RZ.name: Kinh Giáo Giới Phú-Lâu-Na
75PN3a4IsTBNgpgGqKt8RZ.introduction: On the eve of his departure to a distant country, full of wild and unpredictable people, Venerable Puṇṇa is asked by the Buddha how he would respond if attacked there.

20q3hCPzHnhDeOBHV6WaLo.name: Kinh Giáo Giới Channa
20q3hCPzHnhDeOBHV6WaLo.introduction: The monk Channa is suffering a painful terminal illness and wishes to take his own life.

wfimT366HBJTmKWMV8dVt.name: Kinh Giáo Giới Cấp Cô Độc
wfimT366HBJTmKWMV8dVt.introduction: As the great lay disciple Anāthapiṇḍika lies dying, Venerable Sāriputta visits him and gives a powerful teaching on non-attachment.

4w9MqeVn6bKNBgp4wnWkms.name: Kinh Phân Biệt Cúng Dường
4w9MqeVn6bKNBgp4wnWkms.introduction: When his step-mother Mahāpajāpatī wishes to offer him a robe for his personal use, the Buddha encourages her to offer it to the entire Saṅgha instead. He goes on to explain that the best kind of offering to the Saṅgha is one given to the dual community of monks and nuns, headed by the Buddha.

25pCeRMTLZpd2CEy5nDk88.name: Kinh Phân Biệt Về Sự Thật
25pCeRMTLZpd2CEy5nDk88.introduction: Expanding on the Buddha’s first sermon, Venerable Sāriputta gives a detailed explanation of the four noble truths.

5l7YzISzkFDpXILLldyvuS.name: Kinh Giới Phân Biệt
5l7YzISzkFDpXILLldyvuS.introduction: While staying overnight in a potter’s workshop, the Buddha has a chance encounter with a monk who does not recognize him. They have a long and profound discussion based on the four elements. This is one of the most insightful and moving discourses in the canon.

Un0kdAClgmzih8HICPyGR.name: Kinh Vô Tránh Phân Biệt
Un0kdAClgmzih8HICPyGR.introduction: Achieving peace is no simple matter. The Buddha explains how to avoid conflict through contentment, right speech, understanding pleasure, and not insisting on local conventions.

3xBbUOUqWnRKKsTFKsuVjd.name: Kinh Tổng Thuyết & Biệt Thuyết
3xBbUOUqWnRKKsTFKsuVjd.introduction: The Buddha gives a brief and enigmatic statement on the ways consciousness may become attached. Venerable Mahākaccāna is invited by the mendicants to draw out the implications.

5lLCUtrdU0rEkSbBeFQfHx.name: Đại Phân Biệt Sáu Xứ
5lLCUtrdU0rEkSbBeFQfHx.introduction: A detailed analysis of the six senses and the relation to emotional and cognitive processes.

4utFoob9W518w5THZmEyKl.name: Đại Kinh Nghiệp Phân Biệt
4utFoob9W518w5THZmEyKl.introduction: Confronted with an overly simplistic version of his own teachings, the Buddha emphasizes the often overlooked nuances and qualifications in how karma plays out.

66xM4vUBtK8wXnXNUSWi6M.name: Tiểu Kinh Nghiệp Phân Biệt
66xM4vUBtK8wXnXNUSWi6M.introduction: The Buddha explains to a brahmin how your deeds in past lives affect you in this life.

6Khk3ykK45JzJWX5MIqdkG.name: Kinh Lomasakangiya Nhất Dạ Hiền Giả
6Khk3ykK45JzJWX5MIqdkG.introduction: A monk who does not know the verses from MN 131 is encouraged by a deity to learn them.

5CtmoXZdQsW2ShTO3959oi.name: Kinh Đại Ca-Chiên-Diên Nhất Dạ Hiền Giả
5CtmoXZdQsW2ShTO3959oi.introduction: The verses from MN 131 are explained in a different way by Venerable Mahakaccāna.

6NeMs5eUCiU8HCAPP1knnE.name: Kinh A-Nan Nhất Dạ Hiền Giả
6NeMs5eUCiU8HCAPP1knnE.introduction: The same discourse as MN 131, but spoken by Venerable Ānanda.

4P2f5Capc9dNmh75p11jt8.name: Kinh Nhất Dạ Hiền Giả
4P2f5Capc9dNmh75p11jt8.introduction: This discourse opens with a short but powerful set of verses extolling the benefits of insight into the here and now, followed by an explanation.

w1nt3cyHwiECHpW8VJL7X.name: Kinh Thiên Xứ
w1nt3cyHwiECHpW8VJL7X.introduction: Expanding on the previous, this discourse contains the most detailed descriptions of the horrors of hell.

3ZxqlSqQx32glqRpdiv4h.name: Kinh Hiền Ngu
3ZxqlSqQx32glqRpdiv4h.introduction: A fool suffers both in this life and the next, while the astute benefits in both respects.

7Mhl74LQI4EeAfelRzJu8a.name: Kinh Tùy Phiền Não
7Mhl74LQI4EeAfelRzJu8a.introduction: A second discourse set at the quarrel of Kosambi, this depicts the Buddha, having failed to achieve reconciliation between the disputing mendicants, leaving the monastery. He spends time in the wilderness before encountering an inspiring community of practicing monks. There he discusses in detail obstacles to meditation that he encountered before awakening.

3VZqQo8aYK8MBMWnQkH76b.name: Kinh A-Na-Luật
3VZqQo8aYK8MBMWnQkH76b.introduction: A lay person becomes confused when encouraged to develop the “limitless” and “expansive” liberations, and asks Venerable Anuruddha to explain whether they are the same or different.

5QAbiG5BWu03oFhWuHBLy1.name: Kinh Phù-Di
5QAbiG5BWu03oFhWuHBLy1.introduction: Success in the spiritual life does not depend on any vows you may or may not make, but on whether you practice well.

2NwnJZcTfoxZUgrf1HzhZO.name: Kinh Điểu Ngự Địa
2NwnJZcTfoxZUgrf1HzhZO.introduction: A young monk is unable to persuade a prince of the blessings of peace of mind. The Buddha offers similes based on training an elephant that would have been successful, as this was a field the prince was familiar with.

ThuNHvT3KFIg2jytFCFRi.name: Kinh Bạc-Câu-La
ThuNHvT3KFIg2jytFCFRi.introduction: Venerable Bakkula, regarded as the healthiest of the mendicants, explains to an old friend his strict and austere practice. The unusual form of this discourse suggests it was added to the canon some time after the Buddha’s death.

4MhEEElTAkjBHBMxlsmr20.name: Kinh Hy Hữu Vị Tằng Hữu Pháp
4MhEEElTAkjBHBMxlsmr20.introduction: Venerable Ānanda is invited by the Buddha to speak on the Buddha’s amazing qualities, and proceeds to list a series of apparently miraculous events accompanying his birth. The Buddha caps it off by explaining what he thinks is really amazing about himself.

7fKF4CMRVM6LIHJep3elVE.name: Kinh Đại Thông
7fKF4CMRVM6LIHJep3elVE.introduction: A group of mendicants have taken to socializing too much, so the Buddha teaches on the importance of seclusion in order to enter fully into emptiness.

73QgAmfVDAmIUhLiBx3kzX.name: Kinh Tiểu Không
73QgAmfVDAmIUhLiBx3kzX.introduction: The Buddha describes his own practice of the meditation on emptiness.

2Uguz9Va8IqyqYYlI7pIsf.name: Kinh Hành Sanh
2Uguz9Va8IqyqYYlI7pIsf.introduction: The Buddha explains how one can make a wish to be reborn in different realms.

2Vl86qkwFcVQ9yNp3jNQnA.name: Kinh Thân Hành Niệm
2Vl86qkwFcVQ9yNp3jNQnA.introduction: This focuses on the first aspect of mindfulness meditation, the observation of the body. This set of practices, simple as they seem, have far-reaching benefits.

6iVdk5t92Sd4HiOhMjlfpc.name: Kinh Quán Niệm Hơi Thở
6iVdk5t92Sd4HiOhMjlfpc.introduction: Surrounded by many well-practiced mendicants, the Buddha teaches mindfulness of breathing in detail, showing how they relate to the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

7GOX0GzT2ipnpEMVSYEZAc.name: Đại Kinh Bốn Mươi
7GOX0GzT2ipnpEMVSYEZAc.introduction: A discourse on the prerequisites of right samādhi that emphasizes the interrelationship and mutual support of all the factors of the eightfold path.

28dPGYI0W1428V1R92n5Y0.name: Kinh Thôn Tiên
28dPGYI0W1428V1R92n5Y0.introduction: Reflecting on the changes that even geographical features undergo, the Buddha then recounts the names of sages of the past who have lived in Mount Isigili near Rājagaha.

3kEJ2dVIhpsTjriMoNnbb0.name: Kinh Đa Giới
3kEJ2dVIhpsTjriMoNnbb0.introduction: Beginning by praising a wise person, the Buddha goes on to explain that one becomes wise by inquiring into the elements, sense fields, dependent origination, and what is possible and impossible.

3aUxtBgxDmrlxsK3z6G4kM.name: Kinh Nên Hành Trì, Không Nên Hành Trì
3aUxtBgxDmrlxsK3z6G4kM.introduction: The Buddha sets up a framework on things to be cultivated or avoided, and Venerable Sāriputta volunteers to elaborate.

4osjptOeRAZadZGRW2A8LG.name: Kinh Chân Nhân
4osjptOeRAZadZGRW2A8LG.introduction: The Buddha explains that a truly good person does not disparage others or feel superior because of their attainment.

5uwKBbDCqqfTjwrr4gSBBx.name: Kinh Sáu Thanh Tịnh
5uwKBbDCqqfTjwrr4gSBBx.introduction: If someone claims to be awakened, their claim should be interrogated with a detailed series of detailed questions. Only if they can answer them clearly should the claim be accepted.

Jik9FcI0Va0kHCQpVpzaD.name: Kinh Bất Đoạn
Jik9FcI0Va0kHCQpVpzaD.introduction: The Buddha describes in technical detail the process of insight of Venerable Sāriputta. Many ideas and terms in this text anticipate the Abhidhamma.

GmhOk2c1JlmEztEgK0GBL.name: Tiểu Kinh Mãn Nguyệt
GmhOk2c1JlmEztEgK0GBL.introduction: A good person is able to understand a bad person, but not vice versa.

4ic70e5TzVWnUJb7VulHyL.name: Đại Kinh Mãn Nguyệt
4ic70e5TzVWnUJb7VulHyL.introduction: On a lovely full moon night, one of the mendicants presents the Buddha with a series of questions that go to the heart of the teaching. But when he hears of the doctrine of not-self, another mendicant is unable to grasp the meaning.

4mzJV5h5BDaLIj1sKphktf.name: Kinh Gopaka Moggallàna
4mzJV5h5BDaLIj1sKphktf.introduction: Amid rising military tensions after the Buddha’s death, Venerable Ānanda is questioned about how the Saṅgha planned to continue in their teacher’s absence. As the Buddha refused to appoint a successor, the teaching and practice that he laid down become the teacher, and the Saṅgha resolves issues by consensus.

70ZRRBRovV4KoX9yedMK64.name: Kinh Ganaka Goggallàna
70ZRRBRovV4KoX9yedMK64.introduction: The Buddha compares the training of an accountant with the step by step spiritual path of his followers. But even with such a well explained path, the Buddha can only show the way, and it is up to us to walk it.

7gQ4a0yUrTcOHnaW0xAJnX.name: Kinh Bất Động Lợi Ích
7gQ4a0yUrTcOHnaW0xAJnX.introduction: Beginning with profound meditation absorption, the Buddha goes on to deeper and deeper levels, showing how insight on this basis leads to the detaching of consciousness from any form of rebirth.

7wDnsztSI8p0cBft0tjGPA.name: Kinh Thiện Tinh
7wDnsztSI8p0cBft0tjGPA.introduction: Not all of those who claim to be awakened are genuine. The Buddha teaches how true spiritual progress depends on an irreversible letting go of the forces that lead to suffering.

5BULEIIdCkGtbn7JwNVNwS.name: Kinh Làng Sama
5BULEIIdCkGtbn7JwNVNwS.introduction: Hearing of the death of the Jain leader Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, the Buddha encourages the Saṅgha to swiftly resolve any disputes. He lays down a series of seven methods for resolving disputes. These form the foundation for the monastic code.

1wWMI8M4b7oriAy79KjwjF.name: Kinh Nghĩ Như Thế Nào?
1wWMI8M4b7oriAy79KjwjF.introduction: The Buddha teaches the monks to not dispute about the fundamental teachings, but to always strive for harmony.

VdtE2xHZolbMb1UxJ6scN.name: Kinh Năm & Ba
VdtE2xHZolbMb1UxJ6scN.introduction: A middle length version of the more famous Brahmajala Sutta (DN1), this surveys a range of speculative views and dismisses them all.

3nwPQyUenU89MFEbvz2xR2.name: Kinh Devadaha
3nwPQyUenU89MFEbvz2xR2.introduction: The Buddha tackles a group of Jain ascetics, pressing them on their claim to be practicing to end all suffering by self-mortification. He points out a series of fallacies in their logic, and explains his own middle way.

6yfjDtNCCZaFPVbLItQJ8x.name: Đại Kinh Thí Dụ Lõi Cây
6yfjDtNCCZaFPVbLItQJ8x.introduction: Following the incident with Devadatta, the Buddha cautions the mendicants against becoming complacent with superficial benefits of spiritual life and points to liberation as the true heart of the teaching.

3fwxq8TStKRvCU1mel6ENB.name: Đại Kinh Dụ Dấu Chân Voi
3fwxq8TStKRvCU1mel6ENB.introduction: Sāriputta gives an elaborate demonstration of how, just as any footprint can fit inside an elephant’s, all the Buddha’s teaching can fit inside the four noble truths. This offers an overall template for organizing the Buddha’s teachings.

28xpAitjKitDfmKyHXd4Xy.name: Tiểu Kinh Dụ Dấu Chân Voi
28xpAitjKitDfmKyHXd4Xy.introduction: The Buddha cautions against swift conclusions about a teacher’s spiritual accomplishments, comparing it to the care a tracker would use when tracking elephants. He presents the full training of a monastic.

1RiT9avXbpuoxHIYRnjlCo.name: Kinh Sangàrava
1RiT9avXbpuoxHIYRnjlCo.introduction: Angered by the devotion of a brahmin lady, a brahmin visits the Buddha. He positions himself against traditionalists and rationalists, as someone whose teaching is based on direct experience.

31sstnMj5VwAuhwVKnRuQg.name: Kinh Thánh Cầu
31sstnMj5VwAuhwVKnRuQg.introduction: This is one of the most important biographical discourses, telling the Buddha’s experiences from leaving home to realizing awakening. Throughout, he was driven by the imperative to fully escape from rebirth and suffering.

3cIGGpRKCohRmwLBwssVps.name: Kinh Bẫy Mồi
3cIGGpRKCohRmwLBwssVps.introduction: The Buddha compares getting trapped by Māra with a deer getting caught in a snare, illustrating the ever more complex strategies employed by hunter and hunted.

2Oe4cV662vbHEDSKPsKCU0.name: Kinh Trạm Xe
2Oe4cV662vbHEDSKPsKCU0.introduction: Venerable Sāriputta seeks a dialog with an esteemed monk, Venerable Puṇṇa Mantāniputta, and they discuss the stages of purification.

2bwzNu3UxDoWpXOpvzneGL.name: Kinh Ví Dụ Con Rắn
2bwzNu3UxDoWpXOpvzneGL.introduction: One of the monks denies that prohibited conduct is really a problem. The monks and then the Buddha subject him to an impressive dressing down. The Buddha compares someone who understands only the letter of the teachings to someone who grabs a snake by the tail, and also invokes the famous simile of the raft.

3lOsVS1WsjLiBxKfm8L8Lj.name: Kinh Ví Dụ Cái Cưa
3lOsVS1WsjLiBxKfm8L8Lj.introduction: A discourse full of vibrant and memorable similes, on the importance of patience and love even when faced with abuse and criticism. The Buddha finishes with the simile of the saw, one of the most memorable similes found in the discourses.

6rkkqvfRd6hXUYrANscKm2.name: Kinh An Trú Tầm
6rkkqvfRd6hXUYrANscKm2.introduction: In a practical meditation teaching, the Buddha describes five different approaches to stopping thoughts.

5nvc2pyssEwVU1KeHGyrLv.name: Kinh Song Tầm
5nvc2pyssEwVU1KeHGyrLv.introduction: Recounting his own experiences in developing meditation, the Buddha explains how to understand harmful and harmless thoughts, and how to go beyond thought altogether.

bvj103skVRWz6aj2JYXS1.name: Kinh Mật Hoàn
bvj103skVRWz6aj2JYXS1.introduction: Challenged by a brahmin, the Buddha gives an enigmatic response on how conflict arises due to proliferation based on perceptions. Venerable Kaccāna draws out the detailed implications of this in one of the most insightful passages in the entire canon.

1u16hTVmhFqI7iXJxSG5o9.name: Kinh Khu Rừng
1u16hTVmhFqI7iXJxSG5o9.introduction: While living in the wilderness is great, not everyone is ready for it. The Buddha encourages meditators to reflect on whether one’s environment is genuinely supporting their meditation practice, and if not, to leave.

2tB7M1egemn9U4NQ1Zw4Ym.name: Kinh Tâm Hoang Vu
2tB7M1egemn9U4NQ1Zw4Ym.introduction: The Buddha explains various ways one can become emotionally cut off from one’s spiritual community.

6KbGu9ktd9Drp8sl0GHp6y.name: Kinh Tư Lượng
6KbGu9ktd9Drp8sl0GHp6y.introduction: Venerable Moggallāna raises the topic of admonishment, without which healthy community is not possible. He lists a number of qualities that will encourage others to think it worthwhile to admonish you in a constructive way.

4XNfSUyjQC0M2I175CijmL.name: Tiểu Kinh Khổ Uẩn
4XNfSUyjQC0M2I175CijmL.introduction: A lay person is puzzled at how, despite their long practice, they still have greedy or hateful thoughts. The Buddha explains the importance of absorption meditation for letting go such attachments. But he also criticizes self-mortification, and recounts a previous dialog with Jain ascetics.

1ZaEipREhc8lKhjnL6Z2gT.name: Đại Kinh Khổ Uẩn
1ZaEipREhc8lKhjnL6Z2gT.introduction: Challenged to show the difference between his teaching and that of other ascetics, the Buddha points out that they speak of letting go, but do not really understand why. He then explains in great detail the suffering that arises from attachment to sensual stimulation.

3mFXxouYvxMuKw8WQcA7aK.name: Đại Kinh Sư Tử Hống
3mFXxouYvxMuKw8WQcA7aK.introduction: A disrobed monk, Sunakkhata, attacks the Buddha’s teaching because it merely leads to the end of suffering. The Buddha counters that this is, in fact, praise, and goes on to enumerate his many profound and powerful achievements.

75br3hf4LqDROYnpYctnJe.name: Kinh Niệm Xứ
75br3hf4LqDROYnpYctnJe.introduction: Here the Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This collects many of the meditation teachings found throughout the canon, especially the foundational practices focusing on the body, and is regarded as one of the most important meditation discourses.

5vjMxQia89jpt8sOIBBWCp.name: Kinh Chánh Tri Kiến
5vjMxQia89jpt8sOIBBWCp.introduction: Venerable Sāriputta gives a detailed explanation of right view, the first factor of the noble eightfold path. At the prompting of the other mendicants, he approaches the topic from a wide range of perspectives.

1gme8XVF6DJ8rmA3rOVF56.name: Kinh Đoạn Giảm
1gme8XVF6DJ8rmA3rOVF56.introduction: The Buddha differentiates between peaceful meditation and spiritual practices that encompass the whole of life. He lists forty-four aspects, which he explains as “effacement”, the wearing away of conceit.

a36LrU9ir7ja8EFNJ5DUK.name: Kinh Ví Dụ Tấm Vải
a36LrU9ir7ja8EFNJ5DUK.introduction: The many different kinds of impurities that defile the mind are compared to a dirty cloth. When the mind is clean we find joy, which leads to states of higher consciousness. Finally, the Buddha rejects the Brahmanical notion that purity comes from bathing in sacred rivers.

5A3Ii0hDdiIH8mTTfWhoSJ.name: Kinh Ước Nguyện
5A3Ii0hDdiIH8mTTfWhoSJ.introduction: According to the Buddha, careful observance of ethical precepts is the foundation of all higher achievements in the spiritual life.

7JivM0M2n5tTACeqydUOAP.name: Kinh Không Uế Nhiễm
7JivM0M2n5tTACeqydUOAP.introduction: The Buddha’s chief disciples, Sāriputta and Moggallāna, use a simile of a tarnished bowl to illustrate the blemishes of the mind and conduct. They emphasize how the crucial thing is not so much whether there are blemishes, but whether we are aware of them.

3uwCrKUC5q2yKqOAbwFzPY.name: Kinh Sợ Hãi Khiếp Đảm
3uwCrKUC5q2yKqOAbwFzPY.introduction: The Buddha explains the difficulties of living in the wilderness, and how they are overcome by purity of conduct and meditation. He recounts some of the fears and obstacles he faced during his own practice.

5yB3CNFHrmaY34eGZsUuLG.name: Kinh Thừa Tự Pháp
5yB3CNFHrmaY34eGZsUuLG.introduction: Some of the Buddha’s students inherit from him only material profits and fame. But his true inheritance is the spiritual path, the way of contentment. Venerable Sāriputta explains how by following the Buddha’s example we can experience the fruits of the path.

7lMafS0UZ3E9t8L7FNmJ1u.name: Kinh Pháp Môn Căn Bản
7lMafS0UZ3E9t8L7FNmJ1u.introduction: The Buddha examines how the notion of a permanent self emerges from the process of perception. A wide range of phenomena are considered, embracing both naturalistic and cosmological dimensions. An unawakened person interprets experience in terms of a self, while those more advanced have the same experiences without attachment.

387clgpWU49DbEvBUW2JCx.name: Kinh Thập Thượng
387clgpWU49DbEvBUW2JCx.introduction: This is similar to the previous, but with a different manner of exposition. These two discourses anticipate some of the methods of the Abhidhamma.

2Mnmul1flji5GCcA4DyzOW.name: Kinh Phúng Tụng
2Mnmul1flji5GCcA4DyzOW.introduction: The Buddha encourages Venerable Sāriputta to teach the mendicants, and he offers an extended listing of Buddhist doctrines arranged in numerical sequence.

3nytcu1JJdAlY58Md8k8gA.name: Kinh A-Sá-Nang-Chi
3nytcu1JJdAlY58Md8k8gA.introduction: Mighty spirits hold a congregation, and warn the Buddha that, since not all spirits are friendly, the mendicants should learn verses of protection.

7KkC63tm3mGbCivkBEYOCn.name: Kinh Giáo Thọ Thi-Ca-La-Việt
7KkC63tm3mGbCivkBEYOCn.introduction: The Buddha encounters a young man who honors his dead parents by performing rituals. The Buddha recasts the meaningless rites in terms of virtuous conduct. This is the most detailed discourse on ethics for lay people.

1tVU2kZ9oTlxVV8tMNEbBz.name: Kinh Chuyển Luân Thánh Vương Sư Tử Hống
1tVU2kZ9oTlxVV8tMNEbBz.introduction: In illustration of his dictum that one should rely on oneself, the Buddha gives a detailed account of the fall of a kingly lineage of the past, and the subsequent degeneration of society. This process, however, is not over, as the Buddha predicts that eventually society will fall into utter chaos. But far in the future, another Buddha, Metteyya, will arise in a time of peace and plenty.

hrePzUOyLaNzNEuY5cb99.name: Kinh Ba-lê
hrePzUOyLaNzNEuY5cb99.introduction: When Sunakkhatta threatens to disrobe, the Buddha is unimpressed. Rejecting showy displays of asceticism or wondrous powers, he demonstrates his pre-eminence.

7q6PXyfRlDXyuv9IcQV10c.name: Kinh Ðại Niệm Xứ
7q6PXyfRlDXyuv9IcQV10c.introduction: The Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This discourse is essentially identical to MN 10, with the addition of an extended section on the four noble truths derived from MN 141.

1jLqQ9NPuSIgJacx6PrfxW.name: Kinh Ðế-Thích Sở vấn
1jLqQ9NPuSIgJacx6PrfxW.introduction: After hearing a love song from a god of music, the Buddha engages in a deep discussion with Sakka on the conditioned origin of attachment and suffering.

5mt9eh5xpEI5ZMyoJT7bPR.name: Kinh Ðại Hội
5mt9eh5xpEI5ZMyoJT7bPR.introduction: When deities from all realms gather in homage to the Buddha, he gives a series of verses describing them. These verses, which are commonly chanted in Theravadin countries, give one of the most detailed descriptions of the deities worshiped at the the time of the Buddha.

1MznzHTV14s1Pe5uHQdTN4.name: Kinh Ðại Ðiền-tôn
1MznzHTV14s1Pe5uHQdTN4.introduction: A minor deity informs the Buddha of the conversations and business of the gods.

fzrecym8RnOJPTvl7Ssut.name: Kinh Xà-Ni-Sa
fzrecym8RnOJPTvl7Ssut.introduction: Beginning with an account of the fates of disciples who had recently passed away, the scene shifts to a discussion of Dhamma held by the gods.

1EnAHJ6f9QHbyi8f0l5NiC.name: Kinh Ðại Thiện-Kiến Vương
1EnAHJ6f9QHbyi8f0l5NiC.introduction: An elaborate story of a past life of the Buddha as a legendary king who renounced all to practice meditation.

3P6GXB49P40CTItFKto6eZ.name: Kinh Tam Minh
3P6GXB49P40CTItFKto6eZ.introduction: A number of brahmins are discussing the true path to Brahmā. Contesting the claims to authority based on the Vedas, the Buddha insists that only personal experience can lead to the truth.

1hTUtYwyOxZoagezFnFg3U.name: Kinh Lô-Hi-Gia
1hTUtYwyOxZoagezFnFg3U.introduction: A brahmin has fallen into the idea that there is no point in trying to offer spiritual help to others. The Buddha goes to see him, and persuades him of the genuine benefits of spiritual teaching.

4f26ayUqaQclEUjiZwFzOJ.name: Kinh Cha-Li-Da
4f26ayUqaQclEUjiZwFzOJ.introduction: This discourse is mostly quoted by the Buddha in the previous.

6KerMkjAVBx66gv77jZNHA.name: Kinh Bố-Sá-Bà-Lâu
6KerMkjAVBx66gv77jZNHA.introduction: The Buddha discusses with a wanderer the nature of perception and how it evolves through deeper states of meditation. None of these, however, should be identified with a self or soul.

5mf25cQEz3jjiLHMWIxkRs.name: Kinh Ðại Bát-Niết-Bàn
5mf25cQEz3jjiLHMWIxkRs.introduction: The longest of all discourses, this extended narrative tells of the events surrounding the Buddha’s death. Full of vivid and moving details, it is an ideal entry point into knowing the Buddha as a person, and understanding how the Buddhist community coped with his passing.

2YMy30cLTwKaO7n11ZZnVQ.name: Kinh Kiên Cố
2YMy30cLTwKaO7n11ZZnVQ.introduction: The Buddha refuses to perform miracles, explaining that this is not the right way to inspire faith. He goes on to tell the story of a monk whose misguided quest for answers led him as far as Brahmā.

4vKyJBw04b39jhjR7UsiZ.name: Kinh Ðại Sư Tử Hống
4vKyJBw04b39jhjR7UsiZ.introduction: The Buddha is challenged by a naked ascetic on the topic of spiritual austerities. He points out that it is quite possible to perform all kinds of austere practices without having any inner purity of mind.

CUDS6ha6zIJPd3S1kuVTQ.name: Kinh Ðại Duyên
CUDS6ha6zIJPd3S1kuVTQ.introduction: Rejecting Venerable Ānanda’s claim to easily understand dependent origination, the Buddha presents a complex and demanding analysis, revealing hidden nuances and implications of this central teaching.

149YiGuYA6NKOSz3KXW1Mc.name: Kinh Phạm Võng
149YiGuYA6NKOSz3KXW1Mc.introduction: While others may praise or criticize the Buddha, they tend to focus on trivial details. The Buddha presents an analysis of 62 kinds of wrong view, seeing through which one becomes detached from meaningless speculations.

0118HXqEpk33OLZloCZKrH.name: Kinh Tu-Ba
0118HXqEpk33OLZloCZKrH.introduction: Shortly after the Buddha’s death, Venerable Ānanda is invited to explain the core teachings.

2AIHNSG4Ox5MUPvNq0deTh.name: Kinh Ma-Ha-Li
2AIHNSG4Ox5MUPvNq0deTh.introduction: The Buddha explains to a diverse group of lay people how the results of meditation depend on the manner of development.

3wJbxHh0LU7r0pMmrV7lWB.name: Kinh Chủng Ðức
3wJbxHh0LU7r0pMmrV7lWB.introduction: A reputed brahmin visits the Buddha, despite the reservations of other brahmins. They discuss the true meaning of a brahmin, and the Buddha skillfully draws him around to his own point of view.

7m0jV0NI5kjULadAX70WsY.name: Kinh Cứu-La-Ðàn-Ðầu
7m0jV0NI5kjULadAX70WsY.introduction: A brahmin wishes to undertake a great sacrifice, and asks for the Buddha’s advice. The Buddha tells a legend of the past, in which a king is persuaded to give up violent sacrifice, and instead to devote his resources to supporting the needy citizens of his realm. However, even such a beneficial and non-violent sacrifice pales in comparison to the spiritual sacrifice of giving up attachments.

NvSXLwURStO3P20qRjKFB.name: Kinh Sa-Môn Quả
NvSXLwURStO3P20qRjKFB.introduction: The newly crowned King Ajātasattu is disturbed by the violent means by which he achieved the crown. He visits the Buddha to find peace of mind, and asks him about the benefits of spiritual practice. This is one of the greatest literary and spiritual texts of early Buddhism.

5kKiEtXyKLgMR6WuMtQqeM.name: Kinh A-Ma-Trú
5kKiEtXyKLgMR6WuMtQqeM.introduction: A young brahmin student attacks the Buddha’s family, but is put in his place.

1MquMqAv68xU1dsindfrOx.name: Kinh Tuệ-Túc
1MquMqAv68xU1dsindfrOx.introduction: This is a long and entertaining debate between a monk and a skeptic, who went to elaborate and bizarre lengths to prove that there is no such thing as an afterlife. The discourse contains a colorful series of parables and examples.

6AnSRQaJwHklPWQzRKU60K.name: Kinh Ðại Bổn
6AnSRQaJwHklPWQzRKU60K.introduction: The Buddha teaches about the six Buddhas of the past, and tells a lengthy account of one of those, Vipassī.

kv6KN7Afs0kBIsLZw8Kbi.name: Kinh Ưu-Ðàm-Bà-La Sư Tử Hống
kv6KN7Afs0kBIsLZw8Kbi.introduction: This discourse gives a specially good example of dialog between religions The Buddha insists that he is not interested to make anyone give up their teacher or practices, but only to help people let go of suffering.

cvg5dyQm5nUFrMTAcIiUf.name: Kinh Khởi Thế Nhân Bổn
cvg5dyQm5nUFrMTAcIiUf.introduction: In contrast with the brahmin’s self-serving mythologies of the past, the Buddha presents an account of evolution that shows how human choices are an integral part of the ecological balance, and how excessive greed destroys the order of nature.

4CYJkk6TCy1XQM2O8877Rn.name: Kinh Thanh Tịnh
4CYJkk6TCy1XQM2O8877Rn.introduction: Following the death of Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, the leader of the Jains, the Buddha emphasizes the stability and maturity of his own community. He encourages the community to come together after his death and recite the teachings in harmony.

602fMyvHmzuAUtiF8Hem65.name: Kinh Tướng
602fMyvHmzuAUtiF8Hem65.introduction: This presents the brahmanical prophecy of the Great Man, and explains the 32 marks in detail. This discourse contains some of the latest and most complex verse forms in the canon.

5PQpzSL3sobBDQDVwSUKzt.name: Kinh Tự Hoan Hỷ
5PQpzSL3sobBDQDVwSUKzt.introduction: Shortly before he passes away, Venerable Sāriputta visits the Buddha and utters a moving eulogy of his great teacher.
